body: https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?alloca Some additional fixed had to be done as the Windows build started failing once I fixed the freebsd build. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723)

*[other/travis/toxcore-script, line 13 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723#-L3Uc1QsuF-6b8xtVMtP:-L3Uc1QsuF-6b8xtVMtQ:be0nw3o) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/e6c04ef0287a69c453f129778ef35932e0dff4b2/other/travis/toxcore-script#L13)):*

why is this removed? not needed anymore?

---

*[toxcore/Messenger.c, line 2261 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723#-L3UcExsUYjXCVASKehK:-L3UcExsUYjXCVASKehL:bm3gq83) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/9e2d1c233b702ca4d00ebe3b32616421a30493df/toxcore/Messenger.c#L2261)):*
> ```C
>             uint8_t filenumber = data[0];
> 
> #if UINT8_MAX > MAX_CONCURRENT_FILE_PIPES
> ```

What happens in the case of `UINT8_MAX < MAX_CONCURRENT_FILE_PIPES`? looks a bit like a hack to pass tests for me

---


*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions, all commit checks successful. --- *[toxcore/Messenger.c, line 2261 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723#-L3UcExsUYjXCVASKehK:-L3UdK5yzpfkmCbh_NCw:b-tm2dfo) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/9e2d1c233b702ca4d00ebe3b32616421a30493df/toxcore/Messenger.c#L2261)):*
Previously, sudden6 wrote…
What happens in the case of `UINT8_MAX < MAX_CONCURRENT_FILE_PIPES`? looks a bit like a hack to pass tests for me
This is not to pass tests. The condition below is always false if the cpp condition is false. filenumber is a uint8_t, so can never be larger than 255. This causes compiler warnings and I'd like to avoid those. This has nothing to do with tests. If `UINT8_MAX < MAX...`, then that means we can't even index the highest filenumber. I don't think that's possible without changing the type of filenumber in a lot of places. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723)*

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions, all commit checks successful. --- *[other/travis/toxcore-script, line 13 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723#-L3Uc1QsuF-6b8xtVMtP:-L3UdtQ9P6CPEnkYfU54:bj8l10z) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/e6c04ef0287a69c453f129778ef35932e0dff4b2/other/travis/toxcore-script#L13)):*
Previously, sudden6 wrote…
why is this removed? not needed anymore?
It has never caught any bugs, and seriously slows down windows and freebsd builds. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723)*

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- *[toxcore/Messenger.c, line 2261 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723#-L3UcExsUYjXCVASKehK:-L3UebSCz4M532dxeYS1:bjyqbjw) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/9e2d1c233b702ca4d00ebe3b32616421a30493df/toxcore/Messenger.c#L2261)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
This is not to pass tests. The condition below is always false if the cpp condition is false. filenumber is a uint8_t, so can never be larger than 255. This causes compiler warnings and I'd like to avoid those. This has nothing to do with tests. If `UINT8_MAX < MAX...`, then that means we can't even index the highest filenumber. I don't think that's possible without changing the type of filenumber in a lot of places.
Ok, can we enforce `UINT8_MAX >= MAX_CONCURRENT_FILE_PIPES` by a `#error` + comment? Would make sense against accidental changes IMO. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/723)*

commit.message:
Use <stdlib.h> for alloca on FreeBSD.

https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?alloca

If stdlib.h does not define alloca, and we're using GCC (or Clang), we
define the macro ourselves in terms of a GCC builtin.

https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?alloca

If stdlib.h does not define alloca, and we're using GCC (or Clang), we
define the macro ourselves in terms of a GCC builtin.
